definition: to be awfully (busy etc)
(negative prefix)/not/no
see 可汗[ke4 han2]
can/may/able to/to approve/to permit/to suit/(particle used for emphasis) certainly/very

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
to hand over/to deliver/to pay (money)/to turn over/to make friends/to intersect (lines)/variant of 跤[jiao1]

sentences.english: I've been as busy as a bee all day doing my spring - cleaning.
sentences.chinese: 大扫除使得我一整天一直忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: I would have laughed in different circumstances.
sentences.chinese: 换了是别的场合，她这么说我会笑得不可开交。

sentences.english: Between the planning of the wedding and SOUTHLAND, I'm pretty busy.
sentences.chinese: 在婚礼跟《南国》之间，我有点忙得不可开交了。

sentences.english: Just when I was busiest, he must come worrying.
sentences.chinese: 我正忙得不可开交，他偏要带麻烦的事。

sentences.english: Beihai pavilion every day, from early in the morning is always so busy.
sentences.chinese: 北海亭每逢这一天，总是从一大早就忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: Domestic robots keep busy at the Korea Institute of Science and Technology.
sentences.chinese: 在韩国科技研究中心，家用机器人忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: This week meanwhile, both parties have been pre-occupied with picking their leaders.
sentences.chinese: 同时，本周两党都为安排各自领导人忙的不可开交。

sentences.english: We cannot accept new orders since we have already got our hands full.
sentences.chinese: 我们不能再接受新订单，因为已经忙得不可开交了。

sentences.english: The last week of September 2009 was very busy for Oxfam.
sentences.chinese: 2009年9月最后一个星期，乐施会忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: With the new baby , my daughter really has her hands full.
sentences.chinese: 我女儿新添婴儿后，忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: She came bustling out, wiping her hands on her apron.
sentences.chinese: 她忙的不可开交，把手放在围裙上擦了又擦。

sentences.english: I don't want to see our two neighbours engaged in a brawl.
sentences.chinese: 我不希望我们两家吵架吵得不可开交。

sentences.english: Pumping that water up to her neck.
We used to fight like cats and dogs .
sentences.chinese: 我们过去常打得不可开交。

sentences.english: Tomorrow will be their wedding day. Both their families are busy today preparing for the wedding ceremony.
sentences.chinese: 他们两个明天就要拜天地了，家里人忙得不可开交。

sentences.english: The planners were busy bypassing the Gordian knot.
sentences.chinese: 计划者为回避这个棘手的问题，忙得不可开交。

definition: lit. you die, I live (idiom); irreconcilable adversaries/two parties cannot coexist
neither giving way to the other
at a stalemate/deadlocked/in unrelenting mutual opposition
lit. with swords drawn and bows bent (idiom); fig. a state of mutual hostility/at daggers drawn
to obtain by an effort/to strive to get sth
each sticks to his own view (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
lit. badly burned about the head (from trying to put out a fire) (idiom)/fig. hard-pressed/under pressure (from a heavy workload, creditors etc)
(used with negative) to conclude/(impossible) to end/(can't) finish
lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
each sticks to his own version (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
war of words
bubbling and gurgling/hubbubing/abuzz
lit. wind and rain sweeping through the town (idiom)/fig. a big scandal/an uproar/the talk of the town
dispute/spat/shouting match
lit. isn't that a joy? (quote from Confucius)/fig. (jocularly) extremely/awfully
to become enemies (idiom); to fall out with sb
